Chap. 5
From this day natural philosophy and parti
cularly chemistry became
^
nearly my sole appli
study. I read with ardour m those books
so full of genius and discrimination
th at have been written
which modern
enquirers
on these sub
jects. I attended the lectures, and culti
vated the acquaintance of the men
of science of the university; and I found
even in M
Krempe a great deal
of sound sense & real information
combined it is true with a repulsive
phisiognomy & manners, but not on
that account the less valuable.
In M. Waldman I found a true friend.
His gentleness was never tinged by dg
dogmatism and his instructions were
given with an air of frankness and
good nature that banished ever y idea
of pedantl pedantry. It was perhaps the
amiable character of this man that
enclined me more to the study of that
branch of
science
^
natural philosophy which he professed
than an intrinsic
love for the science itself. But this
X
circumstance
was had
state of mind had
place
X
was
only in the first steps towards the
knowledge;
as
the more fully
I entered
more fully into
the philosophy science
the more I
studied
pursued
it
for its own sake. That application
which at first had been a matter
of
ch duty
^
& resolution,
now became so ardent
and eager that the stars often
dissapeared
^
in the light of
morning
while I was yet
labouring engaged
in my labrotary.
As I applied so closely, it may be
easily conceived that I improved rapid
ly.
It My ardour was indeed the astonish
ment of the students, and my proficiency
that of the master. and Professor Krempe
often asked me with a sly smile
how Cornelius Agrippa went on
;
^
while M. Waldham
expressed the most
heartfelt exultation
in my progress. Two
years passed in this manner during
which I paid no visit to Geneva, but
ws was engaged heart and soul in the
pursuit of some discoveries which I
hoped to make. No one None but those
who have experienced it can conceive
of the enticements of scienceâ€“ especially In
other studies you go as far as others have
d g one before you and there is nothing
more to
learn , know, learn, but in a scientific
pursuit their there is continual
food for discovery and wonder. A mind
of
even moderate capacity who closely pursues
one study must infallibly arrive at
great proficiency in th e at studyâ€”And I
who was continually
applied to
sought the attainment of
one
thing
object
pursuit
and was
wra
pt
up as I was in this sole
I improved so rapidly that at the end
of the two years I made one or two
some
trifling discoveries in the improvement
of some chemical
machines instruments
which pro
cured me great esteem and admiration
at the university. When I arrived at
this
^ point,
and ha v d ng learned
all the professors
at Ingolstadt were
qualified to teach that m
y residence at In
golstadt was
there being no longer conducive to
my improvement, I thought of returning
to my friends and to my native town,
when an incident happened that
protracted my stay.
One of those phÃ¦nonoma which
had
more st
peculiarly attracted my atten
tion was the structure of the human
frame; and indeed that of any animal
endued with life. Whence I often asked
myself did this principle of life proceed.
It was a bold question, and one
that
which
has ever been considered as a mystery.
Yet how many things are we on the
brink of becoming acquainted with
if cowardice or carelessness did
not restrain
us
our enquiries?
. I revolved these circum
stances in my mind and determined
from thenceforth to apply myself more
particularly to th at ose branch es of natural
philosophy which
treats of
relate to
phisiology.
Unless I had been animated by an al
most supernatural enthusiasm, my
application to this study would have
been irksome and almost intolerable.
To examine the causes of life de
we must
first have recou recourse to death.
No is ano anatomy I became acquainted
with the science of anatomy but this
was not sufficient. I must also observe
the natural decay & corruption of the
human body. In my education
my father had taken the greatest
precautions that my mind should
not be impressed by
^
no supernatural
horrors. I do not ever remember
having trembled at
a ghost story
tale of superstition
or
to have feared the apparition of a
spirit
Ligh Darkness had no effect upon my
fancy and a churchyard was to
me merely
^ as the receptacle of
rotten b
bodies deprived of life and
becoming
which
from being the seat of beauty &
strength
^
become food for the worm. But
I A loathsome c But now I was
obliged
led
to examine the
cause cause & progress
of this decay and forced to spend days
and nights in vaults and Charnel
houses. I was obliged My attention was
fixed upon every
horror of whic h
object
calculated to
the most insupportable to the delicacy of
the human feelings.
are suscept able â€“
I saw how the fine form of
a man
was
became
was
degraded and wasted. I beheld the
corruption of death succeed to the bloom
ing cheek of life â€“ I saw how the worm suc
ceeded to
inherited the wonders of the eye and
brain. I paused, examin ed ing
and anal yzed yzing
every minutiÃ¦ of causation
all the minutiÃ¦
of causation
as exemplified in
the change from
life to death, &
death to life,
untill
from the midst of this darkness
a sudden light broke in upon me.
A light so brilliant & wondrous yet
so simple that while it intoxica
ted me
I became dizzy
with the immen
sity of the prospect
which it illus
trated,
I was surprised that I
was among so many men of genius
who had applied to the same science
that I alone should discover
this astonishing secret.
Remember I am
^
not
recording the
no vision
of of a madman â€“ the
sun does not more certainly shine
in the heavens than that wh
at ich
I now
record affirm,
is true. Some miracle
might have produced it. But the
stages of discovery were distinct
and probable. After days and nights
of incredible
toil
labour
and fatigue
I succeeded in discovering the
cause of generation & life. Nay
more, I
was
became
myself capable of
bestowing animation upon lifeless
matter.
My The surprise
that
which I
^
at first experienced
on this discovery soon gave place to
delight and rapture. After such
painful labour
^
After so much
time spent in
painful labour
come
to arrive at onece
at the
obj ect object
summit
of my desires
was the most gratifying circumstance
that could have occurred. But this
discovery was so great and overwhelm
ing that the reflection all the
steps
that
by which I had been progressively led to it were
obliterated.
^
and I
saw
^
beheld
only the result. What
had been the study and desire of the
m wisest men since the creation of
the world was now
in
within
my
hands.
^
grasp;
Not
that, like a magic
sceen scene it
all opened upon me at on e c e
.
on
the contrary
t T he big information
I had obtained was
^
of a nature
rather one that
would
^
to
direct my endeavours. ^
that
than show me the prospect with
any precise certainty.
^ so soon as I
should point
them towards
the object of
my search,
than to exhi
bit that ob
ject already
accomplished. I was like the
Arabian , who had been buried with
the dead, and found a passage to life
aided only by one glimmering and seem
ingly ineffectual light.
I see by your eargerness and the
wonder and hope which your eyes
express, my friend, that you expect to
be informed of the scret secret with
which I am acquainted , ;
but you are
that cannot be.
mistaken .
Listen patiently to the end
of my story and you will easily
perceive why I am reserved upon that
subject.â€” For why shoul d I will not lead you
on, as unguarded and ardent as I then
was, to your
destruct destruction &
infallible misery. Learn from me, if
not by my precepts at least by my exam
ple, how dangerous is the acquirement
of knowledge and how much happier
that man is who believes his native
town the world, than he whonto
aspires to become greater than his
nature allows. will allow.
Chapter 6.
When I found
this
so
astonishing a power
placed
in
within
my hands , I hesitated a long time
concerning the
use
manner in which
I should
make of
employ
it.
Although I conceived myself capable of possessed
the capacity of bestowing animation yet
my to
create

prepare
a
creature
frame

for the
receiving i
reception of
t it
with all its intri
cacies of fibres muscles & veins
must be
still remained
a work of inconceivable labour
2
&
1
diffi
culty . I doubted at first whether I should
attempt the creation of a
creature being
like
unto
myself or one of simpler
organization; b but my imagination
was too much exalted by my first success
to permit me to doubt of my
capacity
ability to
create
give life
a
to
creature
^
being an animal
as complex
and wonderful as man.
' but
Yet
But
when I
when I
looked around for
considered
my materials
they
The materials
at present within
my command
hardly appeared adequate to so ardous
an undertaking;
but I did not despai r.
but I doubted not that I should ul
-timately succeed.
I allowed that my first attempts might
be futile, my operations fail or my work
be imperfect, but I looked around on
I prepared myself
for a multitude
of reverses, my
operations might
be baffled ever
incessantly, & at
last my work be
but imperfect,
yet, when I con
sidered
the improvement
that
which
every day
takes place in science and mechanics
and m my attempt was so much grande r
I was encouraged to hope
and And altho although I could not hope
that my
present attempts would
s
at le
be in every
at least
^
lay
the foundations of future success
way perfect ' yet ' but
Nor, could I
consider I did not think that
the magnitude and
grandeur
complexity
of my plan
w as any argument of its impracticabi
lity.
And i I t was with these feelings
^
that
I
began the creation of a human being.
As the
smallness
minuteness
of the parts
were
formed
a
great hindrance to my speed I resolved,
contrary to my first intention, to make
him
the being
of of a gigantic stature; that
is to say about
7
^
seven or eight feet in
height, and proportionably large.
And
after having formed this determination
and having spent some months in
collecting of
successfully
collecting &
arranging
my materials, I began.
No one can conceive my the variety
of feelings which pressed upon me
during this time. When success raised
me
^
to enthusiasm life and death appear
ed to me ideal bounds, which I
should first break thro, and pour a
torrent of light into our dark world.
A new
creation existence
would bless me as its
maker
creator
and source; many happy and
excellent
creatures
beings
natures
would owe their
existence in
being
to me. in manner
in a manner no father could claim
the gratitude of his child
^
so completely as
I should deserve
thiers
And pur
sueing
my
these
reflections if I thought
that if I could bestow
life
animation
upon
upon lifeless matter I might in
process of time (although I now found
it impossible) renew life where
death had apparently devoted the
body to corruption.
These thoughts supported my
spirits while I pursued my
labours
^
undertaking
with unremitting
eagerness
^
ardour . My cheek
was
had grown
pale with study, and pe my person
became emaciated by confinement. sometimes
on the very brink of certainty I faild
yet I still clung to the hope which
the next day or the nexhour next
hour might realize. One secret
which I alone
knew
possessed
was the hope
to which I clung and the moon
gazed on my midnight labours
while with unrelaxed & breathless
eagerness I pursued nature to her
most secret hiding places . But
who shall
know my
^
concieve the horrors of my secret
operatio ns
toil
as I dabbled among the unhallowed
damps of the grave, or tortured the
living animate to ani animal to
animate
my
the
lifeless clay? Now my limbs
now
tremble and my eyes swim with the
rememberance, but then a resistless
and all almost frantic
^
impulse
urged me
on
forward ; I seemed to have lost all
soul or sensation but for one
pursuit. It was indeed a passing trance
that only made me feel with renew
ed acuteness
when
so soon as
the unnatural sti
mulus ceas ed ing
had
to operate, and I had return
ed to my old habits. I collected bones from
Charnel houses and with profane fingers
meddled with the secrets of the human
frame. In a solitary chamberâ€“or rather
cell at the top of the house and seperated
from all other appartments by a gallery
and staircase I h kept my workshop
of filthy creation; my eyeballs were
starting from their sockets in at
tending to the minutiÃ¦ of the my
employment. The dissecting room and
the slaughter house furnished many
of my materials, and often did my
human nature turn from my
occupation but I whilst wal was
still urged
on by an eagerness which perpetually
encreased,
as
I brought my work drew near
^
to
a conclusion.
The sums Summer months
passed while I was thus
employed engaged,
heart and soul, in one pursuit. It
was a most beautiful season: never
did the fields bestow a more plentiful
harvest, or the vines yeild a more
luxuriant vintage. But my eyes were
s hut
insensible
to the charms of nature & the
same feelings which
caused
^
made
me to
neglect the scenes around me caused
me also to forget those friends who
were so many miles absent and whom
I had not seen for so long a time.
I knew that my silence disquieted
them and I well remembered the
words of my father. "I know that while
"you are pleased with yourself you
"will thing think of us with affection
"and we shall hear regularly from
"you. And you must pardon me
"if I regard you any interruption
"in your corespondence, as a proof
"that your other
studies
duties
are equal
ly neglected" I rembered knew well
therefore what his opinion would
be
his feelings but I could not tear my thoughts
from my occupation loathsome in
itself but which had taken a n
strong
irresistible hold of my imagni imagination.
I wished as it were to procr procras
tinate
^
all that related to my feelings of affection, untill
the great object
of my affection was
which swallowed up every habit
of my nature should be
compleated.
I then thought that my father
would be in unjust
to
if he
ascribe d my
neglect to vice or faultiness on my
part; but I am now convinced
that
I am
^
he was
X
in the right
in co conceive
X he was in the
right in conceiv
ing that I
should not be
altogether free
from blame.
. A human
being in perfection ough t always to
preserve a cl calm and peaceful
mind and never to allow passion
or
^
a transitory desire to disturb his
tranquillity. I do not think that the pursuit
of knowledge is any exception to this rule.
If the study to which you apply yourself
has a d tendency to weaken your affections
and to destroy your taste for those simple
pleasures in which no alloy can possibly
mix then that study is certainly unlawful
that it is to say on that not befitting to the
human mind. If this
rul rule
was
were
al
ways observed; if no man allowed any
pursuit whatsoever to interfere with
his tranquillity and his domestic affections
Greece had never been enslaved, CÃ¦sar
would have spared his country, America
would have been discovered more gradua l
ly, and the Empires of Mexico & Peru had
not been destroyed.
But I forget that I am moralizing
in the most interresting part of my
tale; and your looks remind me to
proceed.
My father made no reproach in his
letters,
an and only took notice of my
silence by enquiring more particularly
than before what my co occupations
wer were. Winter spring and summer
passed away during my
t l abours but
I did not watch the blossom or the
expanding leaves â€“ sights which before
had alway yeilded me supreme delight.
so
much
deeply was I
taken up with
engrossed in
my
occupation. The leaves of that year
were withered before my work drew
near a close. And now every day shewed
me more plainly how well I had suc
ceeded. But my enthusiasm was
checked by my am anxiety and I appeared
rather like one doomed by slavery
to toil in the mines or any other
unwholsome trade than an artist
occupied in his favourite employment.
Every nigh night a slow fever oppressed
me and I became
nevous
^
nervous
to a degre
most painful degree; a fever
a
dis
ease
I regretted
the
more because I had
hitherto enjoyed excellent health &

boasted of
my
the
firm ness

of my
nerves. But I
believed that exercise and amusement
would soon
driv drive away

such
sym
p toms and I promised myself both
